The Act titled "National Park System Reform Act of 1994" includes the preparation of a National Park System Plan. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 mandates the preparation of a National Park System Plan by the Secretary of the Interior to guide the direction of the National Park System. The plan includes goals, criteria for resource inclusion, and identification of adequate resource representation. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 requires the Secretary of the Interior to prepare a National Park System Plan, which includes identifying appropriate aspects of the national heritage for inclusion in the system and setting priorities for adding themes and resources to better represent the nation's heritage. The plan also outlines the role of the National Park Service in preserving natural areas, ecosystems, and industrial America. The plan also defines the National Park Service's role in preserving natural areas, ecosystems, and industrial America, as well as providing outdoor recreation opportunities. Consultation with various stakeholders is required during the plan's preparation. The plan also defines the National Park Service's role in preserving natural areas, ecosystems, and industrial America, as well as providing outdoor recreation opportunities. Consultation with various stakeholders is required during the plan's preparation, including managing agencies, State and local officials, the National Park System Advisory Board, resource management, recreation and scholarly organizations, and other interested parties as deemed advisable. The Secretary shall transmit the plan to Congress before the end of the third fiscal year after the Act's enactment. SEC. 102 mandates a management review of the National Park System. The Secretary will review the National Park System to consider alternative management options, including partnerships with other entities. A report will be developed listing areas where National Park Service management should be modified or terminated, based on factors like duplication, lack of significance, and cost. The Secretary will review the National Park System for potential changes in management, considering factors like duplication, lack of significance, and cost. Recommendations will be made for areas where National Park Service management should be terminated, with suggestions for alternative management by other entities to protect resources. The Secretary will identify feasible alternatives to National Park Service management for areas of national significance to protect resources and ensure public access. Consultation with various agencies and stakeholders will be conducted, including opportunities for public review and comment. The report developed under this section will be transmitted to Congress within 1 year of completing the plan referred to in section 101 of the Act. The Secretary will consult with agencies and stakeholders, including public review and comment opportunities. The report will be sent to Congress within 1 year, containing recommendations for National Park Service management modifications or termination, and alternative management suggestions. SEC. 103. NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM REVIEW COMMISSION. Establishment of Commission: If the Secretary fails to transmit the report within the specified 1-year period, a National Park System Review Commission will be established to review existing units and suggest alternative management options. The Commission will submit a report to the House Natural Resources Committee and the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee within one year of its establishment. The Commission will identify areas for potential modification or termination of National Park Service management, considering various factors. It will propose alternative management by other entities for listed areas, ensuring protection of resources and public access. Consultations will involve federal agencies, state and local officials, advisory boards, and interested parties. The Commission, consisting of 7 members familiar with the National Park System, will consult with various stakeholders and propose alternative management for listed areas. Appointments will be made by the Secretary, Speaker of the House, and President Pro Tem of the Senate within 3 months. The Commission, comprised of 7 members appointed by the Speaker of the House and President Pro Tem of the Senate, will elect a chair from its members. Vacancies will not hinder the Commission's functions, and a quorum is a simple majority. Meetings will be held quarterly or as called by the chair or majority. Members serve without compensation. The Commission, consisting of 7 members appointed by congressional leaders, will have meetings quarterly or as needed. Members serve without compensation but are entitled to travel expenses. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report to Congress. Staff can be hired, with a limitation on the number of professional staff. The Commission may hire staff to carry out its responsibilities, with a limit on National Park Service employees. Other federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission can also procure temporary services and hold public hearings for its work. The Commission, established under title 5, United States Code, has the power to hold public hearings, make bylaws, and use the United States mails. The Secretary is required to provide requested information to the Commission. The Secretary must provide the Commission with any requested information relevant to their duties and available to the Secretary. SEC. 201. STUDY OF NEW PARK SYSTEM AREAS. Section 8 of the Act of August 18, 1970 is amended to include general authority, remove certain sentences, redesignate a subsection, authorize appropriations, and add a new subsection for studies of potential park additions. Authorization of Appropriations.--''.
By striking subsection (b) and inserting a new subsection (b) for studies of potential park additions. The Secretary is required to submit a list of areas recommended for study for potential inclusion in the National Park System, giving consideration to national significance, suitability, and feasibility criteria. Special consideration is to be given to themes, sites, and resources not adequately represented in the current system. The Secretary must consider national significance, suitability, and feasibility when recommending areas for potential inclusion in the National Park System. Special attention should be given to themes, sites, and resources not well-represented in the current system. No new studies for potential park additions can be initiated after the enactment of this section without specific authorization from Congress. The National Park Service retains the authority to conduct preliminary assessments, gather data, provide assistance, process nominations, update studies, and complete surveys of potential areas. The Secretary must complete studies for potential National Park System inclusions within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment, with public involvement. The Secretary must complete studies for potential National Park System inclusions within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment, with public involvement. Studies consider if the area has nationally significant resources, outstanding recreational opportunities, and is a suitable addition to the system. Factors like natural or cultural resources and feasibility are taken into account. Each study for potential National Park System inclusions must consider factors such as resource rarity, threats, public use potential, costs, and public support. The study should also assess whether direct National Park Service management or alternative protection by other agencies is more suitable. The study for potential National Park System inclusions must assess resource rarity, threats, public use potential, costs, and public support. It should also determine if National Park Service management or alternative protection is more suitable. Each study will identify the most effective way to protect resources and provide for public enjoyment, with a recommendation on the preferred management option. The Secretary will submit a list of areas to Congress at the beginning of each calendar year along with the annual budget submission. The Secretary will submit a list of areas to Congress at the beginning of each calendar year along with the annual budget submission, prioritizing areas for addition to the National Park System based on resource values, threats, and cost factors. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 28, 1994.
